#Text=CHAPTER III
#Text=A conversation with Mr. Merton on Society .
#Text=Mr. and Mrs. James , of Sutton , come up .
#Text=A miserable evening at the Tank Theatre .
#Text=Experiments with enamel paint .
#Text=I make another good joke ; but Gowing and Cummings are unnecessarily offended .
#Text=I paint the bath red , with unexpected result .
#Text=APRIL 19 . — Cummings called , bringing with him his friend Merton , who is in the wine trade .
#Text=Gowing also called .
#Text=Mr. Merton made himself at home at once , and Carrie and I were both struck with him immediately , and thoroughly approved of his sentiments .
#Text=He leaned back in his chair and said :
#Text=“ You must take me as I am ; ” and I replied :
#Text=“ Yes — and you must take us as we are .
#Text=We ’re homely people , we are not swells . ”
#Text=He answered :
#Text=“ No , I can see that , ” and Gowing roared with laughter ; but Merton in a most gentlemanly manner said to Gowing : “ I do n’t think you quite understand me .

#Text=I intended to convey that our charming host and hostess were superior to the follies of fashion , and preferred leading a simple and wholesome life to gadding about to twopenny-halfpenny tea-drinking afternoons , and living above their incomes . ”
#Text=I was immensely pleased with these sensible remarks of Merton ’s , and concluded that subject by saying :

#Text=“ No , candidly , Mr. Merton , we do n’t go into Society , because we do not care for it ; and what with the expense of cabs here and cabs there , and white gloves and white ties , etc. , it does n’t seem worth the money . ”
#Text=Merton said in reference to friends :
#Text=“ My motto is ‘ Few and True ; ’ and , by the way , I also apply that to wine , ‘ Little and Good . ’ ” Gowing said :

#Text=“ Yes , and sometimes ‘ cheap and tasty , ’ eh , old man ? ” Merton , still continuing , said he should treat me as a friend , and put me down for a dozen of his “ Lockanbar ” whisky , and as I was an old friend of Gowing , I should have it for 36s . , which was considerably under what he paid for it .
#Text=He booked his own order , and further said that at any time I wanted any passes for the theatre I was to let him know , as his name stood good for any theatre in London .

#Text=APRIL 20 . — Carrie reminded me that as her old school friend , Annie Fullers ( now Mrs. James ) , and her husband had come up from Sutton for a few days , it would look kind to take them to the theatre , and would I drop a line to Mr. Merton asking him for passes for four , either for the Italian Opera , Haymarket , Savoy , or Lyceum .
#Text=I wrote Merton to that effect .

#Text=APRIL 21 . — Got a reply from Merton , saying he was very busy , and just at present could n’t manage passes for the Italian Opera , Haymarket , Savoy , or Lyceum , but the best thing going on in London was the Brown Bushes , at the Tank Theatre , Islington , and enclosed seats for four ; also bill for whisky .
#Text=APRIL 23 . — Mr. and Mrs. James ( Miss Fullers that was ) came to meat tea , and we left directly after for the Tank Theatre .
#Text=We got a ’ bus that took us to King ’s Cross , and then changed into one that took us to the “ Angel . ”
#Text=Mr. James each time insisted on paying for all , saying that I had paid for the tickets and that was quite enough .
#Text=We arrived at theatre , where , curiously enough , all our ’ bus-load except an old woman with a basket seemed to be going in .
#Text=I walked ahead and presented the tickets .
#Text=The man looked at them , and called out :
#Text=“ Mr. Willowly !
#Text=do you know anything about these ? ” holding up my tickets .
#Text=The gentleman called to , came up and examined my tickets , and said :
#Text=“ Who gave you these ? ” I said , rather indignantly :
#Text=“ Mr. Merton , of course . ”
#Text=He said :
#Text=“ Merton ? Who ’s he ? ” I answered , rather sharply :
#Text=“ You ought to know , his name ’s good at any theatre in London . ”
#Text=He replied :
#Text=“ Oh ! is it ?
#Text=Well , it ai n’t no good here .
#Text=These tickets , which are not dated , were issued under Mr. Swinstead ’s management , which has since changed hands . ”
#Text=While I was having some very unpleasant words with the man , James , who had gone upstairs with the ladies , called out :
#Text=“ Come on ! ”
#Text=I went up after them , and a very civil attendant said :
#Text=“ This way , please , box H. ” I said to James :
#Text=“ Why , how on earth did you manage it ? ” and to my horror he replied :
#Text=“ Why , paid for it of course . ”
#Text=This was humiliating enough , and I could scarcely follow the play , but I was doomed to still further humiliation .
#Text=I was leaning out of the box , when my tie — a little black bow which fastened on to the stud by means of a new patent — fell into the pit below .
#Text=A clumsy man not noticing it , had his foot on it for ever so long before he discovered it .
#Text=He then picked it up and eventually flung it under the next seat in disgust .
#Text=What with the box incident and the tie , I felt quite miserable .
#Text=Mr. James , of Sutton , was very good .
#Text=He said :
#Text=“ Do n’t worry — no one will notice it with your beard .
#Text=That is the only advantage of growing one that I can see . ”
#Text=There was no occasion for that remark , for Carrie is very proud of my beard .
#Text=To hide the absence of the tie I had to keep my chin down the rest of the evening , which caused a pain at the back of my neck .
